content.title: Coarctation of the Aorta Repair Types
content.definition: Surgical and endovascular techniques used to repair coarctation of the aorta, a congenital narrowing typically occurring at the aortic isthmus distal to the left subclavian artery.

concepts.definition: Excision of the coarctation segment with direct reanastomosis.

clinical_features.indication: Short segment coarctation in infants and children
clinical_features.technique: Clamp proximal and distal, resect narrow segment, primary anastomosis
clinical_features.advantages: Removes abnormal tissue, growth potential in children
clinical_features.concerns: Tension if long segment, recurrence with inadequate resection

concepts.definition: Using the left subclavian artery as a patch to widen the coarctation.

clinical_features.indication: Neonates and infants with long segment or arch hypoplasia
clinical_features.technique: Divide subclavian, open longitudinally, fold down as patch
clinical_features.disadvantages: Sacrifices left subclavian artery, left arm claudication

concepts.definition: Widening the coarctation with a prosthetic or autologous patch.

clinical_features.status: Less favored due to aneurysm risk

concepts.definition: Replacement of coarctation segment with tube graft.

clinical_features.materials: Dacron graft sized to normal aorta
clinical_features.considerations: May require CPB for complex cases

concepts.definition: Balloon angioplasty with or without stenting.

clinical_features.balloon: Primary therapy for native coarctation in older children
clinical_features.stent: Covered or bare stents for older children/adults, recoarctation

clinical_features.approach_selection: Age, anatomy, associated defects determine optimal repair
clinical_features.spinal_cord_protection: Collaterals usually well-developed, paralysis risk low

sources.reference: Kenny D et al. Circ Cardiovasc Interv. 2011;4:149-154
